               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-3">
                <span class="post-location">
                </span>
               </div>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div class="date-outer">
           <h2 class="date-header">
            <span>
             July 10, 2018
            </span>
           </h2>
           <div class="date-posts">
            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="7772826995889514041" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="7772826995889514041">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/manderson-on-blindness-visible-law-time.html">
                Manderson on Blindness Visible: Law, Time[,] and Bruegel's Justice @ANU_Law
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-7772826995889514041" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                Desmond Manderson, ANU College of Law; ANU College of Arts and Social Sciences; McGill University Faculty of Law, is publishing
                <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3206477">
                 Blindness Visible: Law, Time and Bruegel's Justice
                </a>
                in Law and the Visual (Desmond Manderson ed., University of Toronto Press, 2018). Here is the abstract.
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 Printed in 1559, Bruegel's 'Justicia' appears at first glance to be a spatial representation of law—a snapshot, a mis en scène. But it is essentially about time. Bruegel’s image overlays three different perspectives on the hitherto unexplored relationship between time, responsibility, and legal authority, revealing the hidden anachronism of law. At the same time, law is shown not merely to be a concept or a symbolic form, but a physical practice engraved in the flesh of those who carry it out and suffer it. Justicia takes as its method art’s anachronic discourse and power of embodiment; and presents as its thesis the role of anachronic discourse and corporeal experience to the law. These insights were pertinent to the situation of law in the sixteenth century, but they are of far broader significance than that.
                </blockquote>
                <br/>
                Download the essay from SSRN at the link.
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">

                   7/10/2018 02:25:00 PM
                  </abbr>
                 </a>

            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="505374218923111674" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="505374218923111674">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/peterson-on-chancellor-kent-and.html">
                Peterson on Chancellor Kent and the Collaborative Era of American Statutory Interpretation
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-505374218923111674" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                Farah Peterson, University of Virginia School of Law, is publishing
                <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3201036">
                 Interpretation as Statecraft: Chancellor Kent and the Collaborative Era of American Statutory Interpretation
                </a>
                in volume 77 of the Maryland Law Review (2018). Here is the abstract.
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 In the Early Republic, American judges acted as collaborators with state legislatures. They took on interpretive powers that blurred the line modern scholars expect to find between the legislative and judicial branches of government.
                </blockquote>
                Download the article from SSRN at the link.
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">

              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/television-and-woman-in-jeopardy.html">
                Television and the "Woman in Jeopardy"
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3020243921900325598" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                Allison Yarrow investigates the plight of the "Woman in Jeopardy" on 1990s television. She points both to real-life women like Mary Jo Buffacuoco, Amy Fisher's victim, and the numerous main characters of made for tv movies that populated the airwaves. Says Ms. Yarrow in part,
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 Network executives told the press that Jep films empowered women characters, enabling them to assume qualities they weren’t normally given by television writers and producers. Women in Jep could “cajole, demand, infiltrate, investigate and settle scores,” all in the name of offing a threatening man-monster, said one magazine. These women didn’t need a hero to free them; they could save themselves, and did so in an arsenal of skimpy outfits. Of course, in reality, Jep was a gimmick to sate audiences who wanted to see women suffer and dole out abuse on TV.
                </blockquote>
                More
                <a href="https://lithub.com/why-was-90s-tv-full-of-violence-against-women/" target="_blank">
                 here
                </a>
                from LitHub.
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">

              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/critical-legal-conference-2018.html">
                Critical Legal Conference 2018: Registration Open
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6980982356377493680" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                From the CLC2018 Committee:
                <br/>
                <blockquote class="tr_bq">
                 <br/>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                  We are pleased to announce that
 registration is now open for the Critical Legal Conference 2018: Regeneration
 at The Open University, Milton Keynes, UK from 6-8
                  <sup>
                   th
                  </sup>
                  September 2018
 (
                  <a href="http://law-school.open.ac.uk/events/critical-legal-conference-2018-doctoral-workshop">
                   doctoral
 workshop
                  </a>
                  on afternoon of 5
                  <sup>
                   th
                  </sup>
                  September).
                 </span>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                 </span>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                  Registration is through Eventbrite and you
 can find a link to register, as well as the Call for papers and panels and
 other conference details on the
                  <a href="http://law-school.open.ac.uk/events/CLC-2018">
                   Conference webpage
                  </a>
                  .
                  <br/>
                 </span>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                 </span>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                  The Call for Papers and Panels will close
 at midnight on 31 July 2018. Registration will close at midday on
                  <b>
                   Monday
 6
                   <sup>
                    th
                   </sup>
                   August 2018.
                  </b>
                 </span>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                 </span>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                  If you are a doctoral student and wish to
 attend the doctoral workshop on 5th September, please register for a free
 doctoral workshop ticket
                  <b>
                   in addition to
                  </b>
                  your main conference ticket.
                 </span>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                 </span>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                  Please do circulate this information among
 interested colleagues.
                 </span>
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                 </span>
                </blockquote>
                <blockquote class="tr_bq">
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                  Best wishes
                 </span>
                </blockquote>
                <blockquote class="tr_bq">
                 <span lang="EN-GB" style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB;'>
                  CLC2018 Committee
                 </span>
                </blockquote>
                <br/>

          <div class="date-outer">
           <h2 class="date-header">
            <span>
             July 9, 2018
            </span>
           </h2>
           <div class="date-posts">
            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="1500450791335968265" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="1500450791335968265">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/bond-on-atticus-finch-in-law-school.html">
                Bond on Atticus Finch in the Law School Classroom
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1500450791335968265" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                Cynthia D. Bond, The John Marshall Law School, is publishing
                <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3200180">
                 To Kill a Lawyer-Hero: Atticus Finch in the Law School Classroom
                </a>
                in volume 45 of the Rutgers Law Record (2018). Here is the abstract.
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 This article addresses the well-known lawyer character from Harper Lee’s novel and subsequent film, To Kill a Mockingbird. For years, legal scholars have rhapsodized about Atticus Finch as the ultimate “lawyer-hero” and role model for aspiring attorneys, with little dissent. When Lee’s literary executor published an early draft version of the novel entitled Go Set a Watchman in 2015, many readers were shocked to encounter an Atticus Finch who was an apologist for segregation and the leader of a White Citizens Council chapter. This article reflects on evolving views of Finch as lawyer-hero, examining how he plays in the contemporary law school classroom. This article argues that, regardless of Go Set a Watchman, law professors should be teaching Atticus Finch critically given the unacknowledged white privilege embedded in To Kill a Mockingbird. Yet how can we critique Finch and still nurture students’ interest in and admiration of social justice lawyering, embodied for some in the mythic lawyer-hero? This article proposes techniques to dismantle the heroic construct surrounding Atticus Finch, shifting the focus from fictional images of the socially-engaged lawyer to students’ own professional aspirations.
                </blockquote>
                The full text is not available from SSRN.
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">
                <span class="post-author vcard">
                 Posted by
                 <span class="fn" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
                  <meta content="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" itemprop="url"/>
                  <a class="g-profile" href="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" rel="author" title="author profile">
                   <span itemprop="name">
                    Christine Corcos
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>
                </span>
                <span class="post-timestamp">
                 Posted on

                  <abbr class="published" itemprop="datePublished" title="2018-07-09T15:45:00-04:00">
                   7/09/2018 03:45:00 PM
                  </abbr>
                 </a>
                </span>

                </span>
               </div>
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-3">
                <span class="post-location">
                </span>
               </div>
              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="https://nyuconnexus.seisan.com/uploads/products/9781479895519/9781479895519_Full.jpg" itemprop="image_url"/>
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="3092950747847260939" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="3092950747847260939">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/mark-goodale-on-anthropology-and-law.html">
                Mark Goodale on Anthropology and Law, a new book from NYU Press @NYUPress
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3092950747847260939" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                ICYMI:
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Mark Goodale, University of Lausanne,
                <a href="https://nyupress.org/books/9781479895519/" target="_blank">
                 Anthropology and Law (NYU Press, 2017).
                </a>
                Here from the publisher's website is a description of the book's contents.
                <br/>
                <br/>
                <blockquote class="tr_bq">
                 <br/>
                 From legal responsibility for genocide to rectifying past injuries to indigenous people, the anthropology of law addresses some of the crucial ethical issues of our day. Over the past twenty-five years, anthropologists have studied how new forms of law have reshaped important questions of citizenship, biotechnology, and rights movements, among many others. Meanwhile, the rise of international law and transitional justice has posed new ethical and intellectual challenges to anthropologists. 
 
 Anthropology and Law provides a comprehensive overview of the anthropology of law in the post-Cold War era. Mark Goodale introduces the central problems of the field and builds on the legacy of its intellectual history, while a foreword by Sally Engle Merry highlights the challenges of using the law to seek justice on an international scale. The book’s chapters cover a range of intersecting areas including language and law, history, regulation, indigenous rights, and gender.  
 
 For a complete understanding of the consequential ways in which anthropologists have studied, interacted with, and critiqued, the ways and means of law, Anthropology and Law is required reading.
                </blockquote>
                <br/>
                <div style="text-align: center;">
                 <img height="200" src="https://nyuconnexus.seisan.com/uploads/products/9781479895519/9781479895519_Full.jpg" width="133"/>
                </div>
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">
                <span class="post-author vcard">
                 Posted by
                 <span class="fn" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
                  <meta content="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" itemprop="url"/>
                  <a class="g-profile" href="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" rel="author" title="author profile">
                   <span itemprop="name">
                    Christine Corcos
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>

                   7/09/2018 10:54:00 AM
                  </abbr>
                 </a>

            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="3586793839104715312" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="3586793839104715312">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/sekhri-on-police-third-degree-and.html">
                Sekhri on Police, the Third Degree, and Indian Courts: 1861-1961
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3586793839104715312" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                Abhinav Sekhri, Delhi High Court, has published
                <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3174042">
                 From 'Bully Boys' to 'Willing Servants': Police, the Third Degree, and Indian Courts: 1861-1961
                </a>
                . Here is the abstract.
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 This paper examines the development of India's statutory and constitutional rules to forestall improper police practices designed to compel self-incrimination. Focusing on the period between 1861-1961, it describes how the judiciary consistently limited the potential of this legal framework to police the police. This was due to the choice of interpreting the rules as a means to ensure reliability of evidence, rather than as safeguards for defendants against police abuses. These widely-held judicial attitudes in colonial courts influenced the interpretation of independent India's constitutional ban against compelled self-incrimination as well. This paper attempts to explain why the Supreme Court chose to adopt a restrictive view of that protection, contesting its legal sufficiency but suggesting that, perhaps, that choice was forced upon a nascent Court which had to pick its battles.
                </blockquote>
                Download the article from SSRN at the link.
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">

                   <span itemprop="name">
                    Christine Corcos
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>

          <div class="date-outer">
           <h2 class="date-header">
            <span>
             July 6, 2018
            </span>
           </h2>
           <div class="date-posts">
            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="http://assets.cambridge.org/97811084/22819/cover/9781108422819.jpg" itemprop="image_url"/>
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="6458057358054278328" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="6458057358054278328">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/from-cambridge-university-press-law-and.html">
                From Cambridge University Press: Law and Literature (edited by Kieran Dolin) @CambridgeUP
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-6458057358054278328" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                ICYMI:
                <a href="http://www.cambridge.org/us/academic/subjects/literature/english-literature-general-interest/law-and-literature?format=HB" target="_blank">
                 Law and Literature
                </a>
                (Kieran Dolin, ed., Cambridge University Press, 2018)(Cambridge Critical Concepts). Here from the publisher's website is a description of the books contents.
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 Law and Literature presents an authoritative, fresh and accessible new overview of the many ways in which law and literature interact. Written by a team of international experts, it provides a multi-focused history of literary studies' critical interest in ideas of law and justice. It examines the effects of law on writers and their work, ranging from classical tragedy to comics, and from East Africa to Elizabethan England. Over twenty chapters, contributors reveal the intricate and multivalent historical interactions between law and literature, both past and present, and trace the intellectual genesis of the concept of law in literary studies, focusing on major developments in the history of the interdisciplinary project of law and literature, as well as the changing ideas of law, and the cultural contests in which it has figured. Law and Literature will appeal to graduates and scholars working on the intersection between law and literature and in key related areas such as literature and human rights.
 
 Provides a multi-focused history of literature's critical interest in ideas of law and justice
 Explores how legal concepts and practices contribute to literary studies
 Presents a history of law and literature, and its contemporary applications
                </blockquote>
                <br/>
                <div style="text-align: center;">
                 <img alt="Law and Literature" height="200" src="http://assets.cambridge.org/97811084/22819/cover/9781108422819.jpg" width="132"/>
                </div>
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">
                <span class="post-author vcard">

                 <span class="fn" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
                  <meta content="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" itemprop="url"/>
                  <a class="g-profile" href="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" rel="author" title="author profile">
                   <span itemprop="name">
                    Christine Corcos
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>
                </span>
                <span class="post-timestamp">
                 Posted on
                 <meta content="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/from-cambridge-university-press-law-and.html" itemprop="url"/>
                 <a class="timestamp-link" href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/from-cambridge-university-press-law-and.html" rel="bookmark" title="permanent link">
                  <abbr class="published" itemprop="datePublished" title="2018-07-06T21:51:00-04:00">
                   7/06/2018 09:51:00 PM
                  </abbr>
                 </a>
                </span>

            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="3217241726374308225" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="3217241726374308225">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/american-society-for-legal-history.html">
                American Society for Legal History Cromwell Fellowships Deadline Extended to 7/20/18
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-3217241726374308225" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                <br/>
                <br/>
                <br/>
                <h1 style="background: white; margin-bottom: 18.75pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 7.5pt;">
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif; font-size: 22.5pt; font-weight: normal; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman";'>
                  ASLH
 Cromwell Fellowships: DEADLINE EXTENDED to JULY 20
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </h1>
                <div style="background: white; margin-bottom: 18.75pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in;">
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif;'>
                  In
 2018, the William Nelson Cromwell Foundation will make available a number of
 $5,000 fellowship awards to support research and writing in American legal
 history by early-career scholars. Early career generally includes those
 researching or writing a PhD dissertation (or equivalent project) and recent
 recipients of a graduate degree working on their first major monograph or
 research project. The number of awards made is at the discretion of the
 Foundation. In the past several years, the trustees of the Foundation have made
 five to nine awards.
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <h2 style="background: white; margin-bottom: 18.75pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 7.5pt;">
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif; font-size: 15.0pt; font-weight: normal; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman";'>
                  Application
 Process for 2018
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </h2>
                <div style="background: white; margin-bottom: 18.75pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in;">
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif;'>
                  The
 Committee for Research Fellowships and Awards of the American Society for Legal
 History (ASLH) reviews the applications and makes recommendations to the
 Foundation. (The Cromwell Foundation was established in 1930 to promote and
 encourage scholarship in legal history, particularly in the colonial and early
 national periods of the United States. The Foundation has supported the
 publication of legal records as well as historical monographs.)
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <div style="background: white; margin-bottom: 18.75pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in;">
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif;'>
                  Applicants
 should submit a description of their proposed project (double-spaced, maximum 6
 pages including notes; include a working title), a budget, a timeline, and a
 short c.v. (no longer than 3 pages). The budget and timeline can be part of the
 Project Description or separate. (There is no application form.) Two letters of
 recommendation from academic referees should be sent directly to the Selection
 Committee via email attachment, preferably as .pdf files. Applications must be
 submitted electronically (preferably in one .pdf file)
                  <b>
                   no later than
 midnight July 20, 2018.
                  </b>
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <div style="background: white; margin-bottom: 18.75pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in;">
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif;'>
                  Please
 send all materials to the Selection Committee at
                  <strong>
                   <span style='font-family: "Georgia",serif;'>
                    &lt;
                    <a href="mailto:cromwell@aslh.net">
                     <span style="color: #d05353;">
                      email
                     </span>
                    </a>
                    &gt;.
                   </span>
                  </strong>
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal" style="background: white; margin-left: 22.5pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in; text-indent: -.25in;">
                 <!--[if !supportLists]-->
                 <span style="color: #222222; font-family: Wingdings; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: Wingdings;">
                  <span style="mso-list: Ignore;">
                   §
                   <span style='font: 7.0pt "Times New Roman";'>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </span>
                 <!--[endif]-->
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif; font-size: 12.0pt;'>
                  Your application
 should make clear the relevance of law to your project. The most successful
 applicants demonstrate how law (broadly construed) is at the center of their
 projects, and how their research will tell us something new about law.
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal" style="background: white; margin-left: 22.5pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in; text-indent: -.25in;">
                 <!--[if !supportLists]-->
                 <span style="color: #222222; font-family: Wingdings; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: Wingdings;">
                  <span style="mso-list: Ignore;">
                   §
                   <span style='font: 7.0pt "Times New Roman";'>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </span>
                 <!--[endif]-->
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif; font-size: 12.0pt;'>
                  Your
 proposal should engage with relevant scholarship in the field. While this
 discussion can be brief, the most successful applicants explain how their
 projects tell us something new.
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal" style="background: white; margin-left: 22.5pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in; text-indent: -.25in;">
                 <!--[if !supportLists]-->
                 <span style="color: #222222; font-family: Wingdings; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: Wingdings;">
                  <span style="mso-list: Ignore;">
                   §
                   <span style='font: 7.0pt "Times New Roman";'>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </span>
                 <!--[endif]-->
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif; font-size: 12.0pt;'>
                  Your
 application should have a clear budget that is specific about how and where you
 plan to spend research funds.
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal" style="background: white; margin-left: 22.5pt; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .5in; text-indent: -.25in;">
                 <!--[if !supportLists]-->
                 <span style="color: #222222; font-family: Wingdings; font-size: 10.0pt; mso-bidi-font-family: Wingdings; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: Wingdings;">
                  <span style="mso-list: Ignore;">
                   §
                   <span style='font: 7.0pt "Times New Roman";'>
                   </span>
                  </span>
                 </span>
                 <!--[endif]-->
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif; font-size: 12.0pt;'>
                  You will
 receive a confirmation email within a few days of submitting your application;
 if you do not receive such an email, please follow up.
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <div style="background: white; margin-bottom: 18.75pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; margin-top: 0in;">
                 <span style='color: #222222; font-family: "Georgia",serif;'>
                  Successful
 applicants will be notified by early November. An announcement of the awards
 will also be made at the annual meeting of the American Society of Legal
 History.
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal">
                 For more information:
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal">
                 <a href="http://aslh.net/about-aslh/honors-awards-and-fellowships/cromwell-fellowships/">
                  http://aslh.net/about-aslh/honors-awards-and-fellowships/cromwell-fellowships/
                 </a>
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoNormal">
                 <br/>

                </div>
               </div>
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-2">
                <span class="post-labels">

               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-3">

            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="723897657948169441" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="723897657948169441">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/phd-fellowship-school-of-humanities-and.html">
                PhD Fellowship, School of Humanities and Digital Sciences: Deadline August 31, 2018 @TilburgU
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-723897657948169441" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                The Tilburg School of Humanities and Digital Sciences of Tilburg University, Tilburg, The Netherlands, invites applications for a four-year PhD position (1,0 fte) in continental political philosophy, the philosophy of culture, or cultural studies, starting  November 1,  2018 or later this year, on the topic of social media and the public sphere.
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Profile
 
 Candidates must hold a MA/MSc degree or equivalent by the time of appointment. Apart from philosophy graduates, candidates with degrees in other relevant disciplines are welcome if they can demonstrate a high level of familiarity with political philosophy or philosophy of culture.
 
  
 
 The selected candidate will be a member of the Graduate School of the Tilburg School of Humanities and Digital Sciences.
                <br/>
                <br/>
                The selected candidate is expected to become member of the research groups Philosophy of Humanity, Culture and Ethics and Rapid Social &amp; Cultural Transformations. They sustain large international networks and regularly organize conferences, workshops and seminars in different traditions of continental philosophy and cultural studies, respectively.
 
  
 
 The candidate is expected to have written a PhD thesis on the topic of social media and the public sphere by the end of the contract.
                <br/>
                <br/>
                The PhD thesis is funded by the Advancing Society: Impact program of Tilburg University, theme: Empowering Resilient Society. The subject of the thesis is expected to be an interdisciplinary research, which combines two or more of the following disciplines:
 
 Philosophy of Humanity, Culture, and Society; Philosophy of Art and Media;  
 Cultural Studies; Literary theory; Online culture and Digitalization
 Philosophy of Law; Critical Theory; Democratic Theory.
  
 
 The thesis will be written under the supervision of Prof. M.S. Prange (Department of Philosophy); Prof. O.M. Heynders (Department Cultural Studies); Dr. M. Bot (Department of Law).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                This PhD project explores possibilities for democratic communication in an age of social media and digital technologies. The project explores how social media and digital technologies can facilitate free communication among equal members of democratic publics, and it explores how social media and digital technologies can undermine such free communication, for instance through bots and trolling and by providing platforms for narratives, symbols, and sentiments of inequality, particularly of race, religion, gender and sexuality.
                <br/>
                <br/>
                More about the position, including application information,
                <a href="https://career5.successfactors.eu/career?career_ns=job_listing&amp;company=S003974031P&amp;navBarLevel=JOB_SEARCH&amp;rcm_site_locale=en_US&amp;career_job_req_id=14381&amp;selected_lang=en_US&amp;jobAlertController_jobAlertId=&amp;jobAlertController_jobAlertName=&amp;_s.crb=j3Dehu%2bO1g55ruPCTifSUoFu6dI%3d">
                 here.
                </a>
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">

          <div class="date-outer">
           <h2 class="date-header">
            <span>
             July 5, 2018
            </span>
           </h2>
           <div class="date-posts">
            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="5051563443126619617" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="5051563443126619617">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/cfp-panel-art-history-and-making-of.html">
                CFP: Panel: Art, History, and the Making of European Identity:  Deadline July 15, 2018 @thomgiddens
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5051563443126619617" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                <br/>
                <span style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 11.0pt;'>
                 Call
 for Papers for the Panel: Art, History and the Making of European Identity
                </span>
                <span style='color: #333333; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 10.0pt;'>
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </span>
                <br/>
                <div class="MsoNormal">
                 <span style='color: black; font-family: "Helvetica",sans-serif; font-size: 11.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman";'>
                  <br/>
                  As part of
                  <br/>
                  8th Euroacademia International Conference
                  <br/>
                  Europe Inside-Out: Europe and Europeanness Exposed to Plural Observers
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  Lucca, Tuscany, Italy, 28 – 30 September 2018
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  Deadline for paper proposals: 15th of July 2018
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  Art, History and the Making of European Identity
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  Panel Description
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  Identities are socially attributed imaginary significations. They are part of
 the dynamic projects of individual and social autonomy (C. Castoriadis).
 Nothing shapes, represents or reflects better the imaginary constructions of
 particular societies than arts. The artistic perception and practice are often
 identity making processes while the object of art can be a direct or indirect
 embodiment of experienced identities. At the outcome line of the process of
 artistic creation, the perception of the objects of art as oeuvre is an
 identification with cultural claims for specific aesthetic standards.
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  Art has a tremendous impact in indicating or shaping various dimensions of
 multilayered identities. Trough time art represented or influenced human
 visions of life and death, natural or supra-natural, meanings of life and daily
 practices, beliefs and their expression, history and change, places and
 differences. Art is simultaneously a process of building contextual cultural
 identifications and an instrument for cross-cultural dialogue. Arts supported
 the symbolic legitimating of various political orders and had an essential role
 in the creation of national identities. Arts shaped cultural aspirations and
 credos as an effective element of cultural innovation, change and openness to
 new. Through imaginary representations, art inserted divisions and differences
 among cultures and self-perceptions of people yet also opened the path of
 curiosity for the other and the emergence of trans-cultural dialogue. As
 artistic visions touched upon the most intimate identitarian representations of
 individuals and societies, they exercise a fundamental role in the developments
 and dynamics of identity making processes. Arts deeply touched on social and
 self-representation through sculpture and portraiture, on civic identities
 through defining social spaces in architecture or quotidian perceptions through
 design, on social or political allegiances through symbols, iconic objects and
 cultural diplomacy, on acting identities through theater, literature or
 performance arts, on the formation of transnational and global symbols. They
 exercised an essential impact on the formation of social memories or in
 addressing inclusion and exclusion nexuses for the marginalized or oppressed.
 Art is as well one of the important modes for asserting identities.
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  This panel addresses explicitly and invites the theoretical or applied studies
 that relate artistic manifestations with identity making processes. As the
 universe of reflection and research on the topics involved are virtually
 unlimited and impossible to anticipate in full diversity, we welcome
 contributions that add value or challenges to the discussion of the topic.
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  Some suggested topics for the panel are:
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  •       European Art and identity: a
 bidirectional influence
                  <br/>
                  •       Arts and the formation of social
 imaginary in Europe
                  <br/>
                  •       Art as search for self-expression and
 identity
                  <br/>
                  •       History, memory, art and identity in
 Europe: from literature to visual and performing arts
                  <br/>
                  •       Renaissance and humanism influence on
 modern identity
                  <br/>
                  •       Art and the creation of national
 identities in Europe
                  <br/>
                  •       Modern art and novelty as a value
                  <br/>
                  •       Portraiture and identity: from painting
 to sculpture and photography
                  <br/>
                  •       Performing identities: identity and
 performance in literature, theater and the performing arts
                  <br/>
                  •       The body in art
                  <br/>
                  •       Art and expressions of gender identity
                  <br/>
                  •       Photography and identity making: from
 single images to serial portraits
                  <br/>
                  •       Identity and migration or displacement in
 art
                  <br/>
                  •       Alberto Giacometti and Constantin
 Brancusi: the human and the absolute
                  <br/>
                  •       Picasso and Modigliani: images of a
 deeper self
                  <br/>
                  •       Cindy Sherman: the nature of
 representation and construction of identity
                  <br/>
                  •       Architecture and urban vision: from civic
 identities to globalization
                  <br/>
                  •       Contemporary design and the visions of
 life and the self
                  <br/>
                  •       Displaying allegiance: from ideological
 art to political symbols
                  <br/>
                  •       Fashion and social staging of personal
 identity
                  <br/>
                  •       Cinematography and identitarian
 representations
                  <br/>
                  •       Art and cross-cultural dialogue
                  <br/>
                  •       Art and post-colonialism
                  <br/>
                  •       Repressed identities and arts
                  <br/>
                  •       Art and search for recognition:
 expressing cultural heritage
                  <br/>
                  •       Art, infinite reproduction and the global
 village
                  <br/>
                  •       Kitsch and identity
                  <br/>
                  •       Museums, galleries and exhibitions:
 displaying identities
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  Please apply on-line or submit abstracts of less than 300 words together with
 the details of affiliation by 15th of July 2018 to
                  <a href="mailto:application@euroacademia.org">
                   application@euroacademia.org
                  </a>
                  <br/>
                  <br/>
                  For complete details please see the conference website:
                  <br/>
                  <a href="http://euroacademia.eu/conference/8eio/">
                   http://euroacademia.eu/conference/8eio/
                  </a>
                  <o:p>
                  </o:p>
                 </span>
                </div>
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Via @thomgiddens
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>

          <div class="date-outer">
           <h2 class="date-header">
            <span>
             July 3, 2018
            </span>
           </h2>
           <div class="date-posts">
            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="https://images.springer.com/sgw/books/medium/9783319907864.jpg" itemprop="image_url"/>
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="9183855057918277927" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="9183855057918277927">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/the-art-of-law-artistic-representations.html">
                The Art of Law: Artistic Representations and Iconography of Law and Justice in Context, from the Middle Ages to the First World War (forthcoming from Springer Publishing)
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-9183855057918277927" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                Forthcoming from Springer:
                <a href="https://www.springer.com/us/book/9783319907864" target="_blank">
                 The Art of Law: Artistic Representations and Iconography of Law and Justice in Context, from the Middle Ages to the First World War
                </a>
                (S. Huygebaert, G. Martyn, V. Paumen, E. Bousmar, and X. Rousseaux, eds., 2018) (Ius Gentium: Comparative Perspectives on Law and Justice).
 
 Here from the publisher's website is a description of the book's contents.
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 The contributions to this volume were written by historians, legal historians and art historians, each using his or her own methods and sources, but all concentrating on topics from the broad subject of historical legal iconography. How have the concepts of law and justice been represented in (public) art from the Late Middle Ages onwards? Justices and rulers had their courtrooms, but also churches, decorated with inspiring images. At first, the religious influence was enormous, but starting with the Early Modern Era, new symbols and allegories began appearing. Throughout history, art has been used to legitimise the act of judging, but artists have also satirised the law and the lawyers; architects and artisans have engaged in juridical and judicial projects and, in some criminal cases, convicts have even been sentenced to produce works of art. The book illustrates and contextualises the various interactions between law and justice on the one hand, and their artistic representations in paintings, statues, drawings, tapestries, prints and books on the other.
                </blockquote>
                <div style="text-align: center;">
                 <img height="200" src="https://images.springer.com/sgw/books/medium/9783319907864.jpg" width="133"/>
                </div>
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">
                <span class="post-author vcard">
                 Posted by
                 <span class="fn" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
                  <meta content="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" itemprop="url"/>
                  <a class="g-profile" href="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" rel="author" title="author profile">
                   <span itemprop="name">
                    Christine Corcos
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>
                </span>

                   7/03/2018 12:41:00 PM
                  </abbr>
                 </a>

             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="736025948661312099" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="736025948661312099">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/deadline-extended-abstract-submission.html">
                Deadline Extended: Abstract Submission, Conference on Qualitative Research in Law, October 26, 2018
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-736025948661312099" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                <br/>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 Conference on Qualitative Research in Law - to be held on
 26 Oct 2018 in Brno, Czech Republic
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 We invite all who are interested in qualitative and
 interpretive methods in legal research. Contributions should focus on the
 methodological aspect of qualitative research: methods of data collection,
 interpretation of various types of data, and experience with this type of
 research in law in general. We are interested in research of anthropological,
 linguistic, ethnographic, narratological, sociological and other related fields
 dealing with law, its position and influence on society, the content of legal
 texts or texts about the law.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 - The deadline for abstract submission (maximum length of
 300 words) has been postponed until 15 July 2018, on
                 <a href="mailto:qrlconference@law.muni.cz">
                  qrlconference@law.muni.cz
                 </a>
                 .
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 - Notification will be sent to authors until August 13,
 2018.
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 More info:
                 <a href="http://qrlconference.wordpress.com/">
                  http://qrlconference.wordpress.com/
                 </a>
                 <o:p>
                 </o:p>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 <br/>
                 Via @thomgiddens
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <div class="MsoPlainText">
                 <br/>
                </div>
                <br/>
               </div>

                <span class="post-author vcard">
                 Posted by
                 <span class="fn" itemprop="author" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
                  <meta content="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" itemprop="url"/>
                  <a class="g-profile" href="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" rel="author" title="author profile">
                   <span itemprop="name">
                    Christine Corcos
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>
                </span>
                <span class="post-timestamp">
                 Posted on
                 <meta content="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/deadline-extended-abstract-submission.html" itemprop="url"/>
                 <a class="timestamp-link" href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/07/deadline-extended-abstract-submission.html" rel="bookmark" title="permanent link">
                  <abbr class="published" itemprop="datePublished" title="2018-07-03T10:09:00-04:00">
                   7/03/2018 10:09:00 AM
                  </abbr>
                 </a>
                </span>
                <span class="reaction-buttons">
                </span>
                <span class="post-comment-link">
                 <a class="comment-link" href="https://draft.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=15363376&amp;postID=736025948661312099" onclick="">
                  No comments:
                 </a>
                </span>

          <div class="date-outer">
           <h2 class="date-header">
            <span>
             June 29, 2018
            </span>
           </h2>
           <div class="date-posts">
            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="2087693094522268401" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="2087693094522268401">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/06/mcsweeney-on-fiction-in-code.html">
                McSweeney on Fiction in the Code @GSULawReview
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-2087693094522268401" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                Thomas McSweeney, William &amp; Mary Law School, is publishing
                <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3192098">
                 Fiction in the Code
                </a>
                in volume 34 of the Georgia State University Law Review (2018). Here is the abstract.
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 One of the major branches of the field of law and literature is often described as “law as literature.” Scholars of law as literature examine the law using the tools of literary analysis. The scholarship in this subfield is dominated by the discussion of narrative texts: confessions, victim-impact statements, and, above all, the judicial opinion. This article will argue that we can use some of the same tools to help us understand non-narrative texts, such as law codes and statutes. Genres create expectations. We do not expect a law code to be literary. Indeed, we tend to dissociate the law code from the kind of imaginative fiction we expect to find in a narrative text. This article will take a historical example, the medieval Icelandic legal manuscript known as Konungsbók, and examine it for its fictional elements. This article will examine Konungsbók for the ways in which it creates an imagined world, populated by free, equal householders, a world that was very different from the Iceland in which its creator lived. Its creator may have created it less to tell his reader anything about the law as it stood in thirteenth-century Iceland than as an elegy to a world he thought he had lost. It therefore stands as a testament to the law code’s literary potential.
                </blockquote>
                Download the article from SSRN at the link.
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">

              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/06/a-new-series-on-movies-and-popular.html">
                A New Series on Movies and Popular Culture From Rutgers University Press @RutgersUPress
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1416172623279245595" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                <a href="https://www.rutgersuniversitypress.org/search-list?series=quick-takes-movies-and-popular-culture" target="_blank">
                 Of interest from Rutgers University Pres
                </a>
                s: Quick Takes: Movies and Popular Culture
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Blair Davis, Comic Book Movies (Rutgers University Press, 2018).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Steven Gerrard, The Modern British Horror Film (Rutgers University Press, 2018).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Barry Keith Grant, Monster Cinema (Rutgers University Press, 2018).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Ian Olney, Zombie Cinema (Rutgers University Press, 2017).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Valerie Orlando, New African Cinema (Rutgers University Press (2017).
                <br/>

                Stephen Prince, Digital Cinema (Rutgers University Press, 2019) (forthcoming).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Steven Shaviro, Digital Music Videos (Rutgers University Press, 2017).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                David Sterritt, Rock 'n' Roll Movies (Rutgers University Press, 2017).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                John Wills, Disney Culture (Rutgers University Press, 2017).

          <div class="date-outer">
           <h2 class="date-header">
            <span>
             June 27, 2018
            </span>
           </h2>
           <div class="date-posts">
            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="1302711896873268238" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="1302711896873268238">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/06/macias-on-utilitarian-constitutionalism.html">
                Macias on Utilitarian Constitutionalism: A Comparison of Bentham &amp; Madison @SIUSchoolofLaw
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-1302711896873268238" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                Steven J. Macias, Southern Illinois University School of Law, is publishing
                <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3189500">
                 Utilitarian Constitutionalism: A Comparison of Bentham &amp; Madison
                </a>
                in volume 11 of the NYU Journal of Law &amp; Liberty (2018). Here is the abstract.
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 Jeremy Bentham (1748–1832), the father of modern utilitarianism, had much in common, ideologically, with James Madison (1751–1836), the father of the U.S. Constitution. This Article is an attempt to bridge the literature on the two figures and to show that knowledge of Bentham’s constitutional theory is useful in understanding the intellectual environment that produced the U.S. Constitution. Although lawyers’ knowledge of Bentham might be limited to catchphrases such as, “nonsense upon stilts,” or concepts associated with modern surveillance technology like the Panopticon (his design for a prison), Bentham was a serious legal and political philosopher. His interests extended to the United States, so much so, that he engaged in serious analysis of the U.S. Constitution and communicated with leading American politicians, including Madison, Benjamin Franklin, John Jay, Aaron Burr, and John Quincy Adams. This Article demonstrates the similarities of thought between Bentham and Madison and argues that the Constitution is best viewed as a document inspired by, and compatible with, the rationalism represented by English utilitarianism.
                </blockquote>
                Download the article from SSRN at the link.
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">

                  <meta content="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" itemprop="url"/>
                  <a class="g-profile" href="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" rel="author" title="author profile">
                   <span itemprop="name">
                    Christine Corcos
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>

                  <abbr class="published" itemprop="datePublished" title="2018-06-27T11:57:00-04:00">
                   6/27/2018 11:57:00 AM
                  </abbr>
                 </a>

            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="5442516035852075982" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="5442516035852075982">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/06/mcguinness-on-presidential-human-rights.html">
                McGuinness on Presidential Human Rights Talk
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-5442516035852075982" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                Margaret E. McGuinness, St. John's University, School of Law, is publishing
                <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3188953" target="_blank">
                 Presidential Human Rights Talk
                </a>
                in volume 56 of the Washburn Law Review (2018). Here is the abstract.
                <br/>
                <blockquote>
                 In response to Professor Harold Hongju Koh's March 2017 keynote at Washburn University, "The Trump Administration and International Law," this essay examines the diplomatic and political rhetoric deployed by past presidents in support of human rights to argue that such "presidential human rights talk" represented an important element of U.S. human rights policy and promoted the transnational transmission of human rights norms. President Trump's complete abandonment of presidential human rights talk signals an end to what remains of American "human rights exceptionalism." Combined with Trump's "America First" approach to foreign policy, which rejects the value of the international institutions the U.S. helped build and sustain over the past 70 years, the end of presidential human rights talk may also mark the end of U.S. human rights diplomacy.
                </blockquote>
                Download the article from SSRN at the link.
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">

                   <span itemprop="name">

                  </a>

          <div class="date-outer">
           <h2 class="date-header">
            <span>
             June 26, 2018
            </span>
           </h2>
           <div class="date-posts">
            <div class="post-outer">
             <div class="post hentry uncustomized-post-template" itemprop="blogPost" itemscope="itemscope" itemtype="http://schema.org/BlogPosting">
              <meta content="15363376" itemprop="blogId"/>
              <meta content="4738747885278959374" itemprop="postId"/>
              <a name="4738747885278959374">
              </a>
              <h3 class="post-title entry-title" itemprop="name">
               <a href="http://lawlit.blogspot.com/2018/06/mr-and-mrs-loving.html">
                Mr. and Mrs. Loving
               </a>
              </h3>
              <div class="post-header">
               <div class="post-header-line-1">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-body entry-content" id="post-body-4738747885278959374" itemprop="description articleBody">
               <div dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;" trbidi="on">
                You can once again watch the wonderful Mr. and Mrs. Loving, with Timothy Hutton and Lela Rochon (made for television, 1996), and not available on DVD right now, on Amazon Prime. While Nancy Buirski's Loving and The Loving Story, interpretations of the battle Mildred and Richard Loving fought to overturn the Virginia law against miscegenation are also available, I have a soft spot for the 1996 film and am glad to see it for the first time in a number of years.
                <br/>
                <br/>
                I hope it remains on Amazon Prime long enough for my fall class on Law and Society to get a chance to see it. Many of my students would have been five years old or younger when it first aired, and of course wouldn't have been born yet when the U.S. Supreme Court decided the history-making case (1967). Maybe their parents weren't either?
                <br/>
                <br/>
                A short bibliography of the movie and the case.
                <br/>
                <br/>
                ACLU,
                <a href="https://www.aclu.org/issues/racial-justice/loving" target="_blank">
                 Loving: Looking Back at the Landmark Case, Loving v. Virginia
                </a>
                <br/>
                <br/>
                <a href="https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/388/1" target="_blank">
                 Loving v. Virginia, 388 U.S. 1 (1967).
                </a>
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Patricia Hruby Powell, Loving Vs. Virginia: A Documentary Novel of the Landmark Civil Rights Case (Chronicle Books, 2017).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Robert A. Pratt,
                <i>
                 Essay: Crossing the Color Line: A Historical Assessment and Personal Narrative of Loving v. Virginia,
                </i>
                41 Howard L.J. 229 (1997/1998).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                Peter Wallenstein,
                <i>
                 Virginia Hasn't Always Been For Lovers: Interracial Marriage Bans and the Case of Richard and Mildred Loving,
                </i>
                112 The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography 440(4) (2004).
                <br/>
                <br/>
                <br/>
                <br/>
                <br/>
               </div>
               <div style="clear: both;">
               </div>
              </div>
              <div class="post-footer">
               <div class="post-footer-line post-footer-line-1">
                <span class="post-author vcard">

                  <meta content="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" itemprop="url"/>
                  <a class="g-profile" href="https://draft.blogger.com/profile/15379724460486314055" rel="author" title="author profile">
                   <span itemprop="name">
                    Christine Corcos
                   </span>
                  </a>
                 </span>
                </span>
                <span class="post-timestamp">

                  <abbr class="published" itemprop="datePublished" title="2018-06-26T15:12:00-04:00">
                   6/26/2018 03:12:00 PM
